results.content:
I've been enjoying "The Complete Backbone.js Course."  I've found the pacing to be excellent and the presentation clear and concise.  It is easy to follow along because it feels as if you are pair programming the the instructor.  I can pick up both the content and the flow of the work because it is presented as if I'm sitting there with him.

I'm taking this class to prepare for a new project at work which I'm feeling more confident about taking on because of the background I've gained from the course.

The instructor has been attentive to the discussion area.  I spotted a small typo, posted to the discussions, and it was quickly addressed.

results.content:
The "Learn Backbone From Scratch" course by Mosh Hamedani is excellent. The course structure makes the concepts easy to absorb and remember. 
The examples provided with the course are kept simple to focus on the key concepts being taught for each lesson. 
Mosh, the course instructor, speaks clearly and is quite easy to listen to.
I would highly recommend this course as a prerequisite for anyone desiring to learn other Javascript frameworks because it shows the elements of MVC without obscuring it with other details of the framework.

First of all, thanks a million, Mosh! You've saved my time for doing my project. 

This course has a lot of detail for introducing each major element of Backbone, and Mosh makes it really clear and easy to understand these functionalities.

Before taking this course, I've took more then one hour to search all the free tutorials on Youtube, and then I've spent more than 3 hours to watch. But at the end, I was still feeling confuse for many things, and there were so many important parts of Backbone which they didn't mention, for example, how to test your Backbone code.

Now, after go through this course, I am capable to programming with Backbone, and I am going to get my project done.

If you need a good course to teach yourself Backbone in a short time, this will be the one you're searching for.

results.content:
Another great course by Mosh Hamedani (I also took his Angular 2 course)!

Mosh teaches using an easy and friendly style while covering the material in depth and including very good examples. The exercises that he uses are tough but reflect real-world problems. He also provides source code for the solutions, so getting stuck in not an issue.

The final complete project, a Todo List, covers all of the techniques that he taught earlier in the course. He takes the development one step at a time, explaining each part in detail.

I look forward to taking other courses from Mosh in the future.

results.content:
While I did think the course served a really good introduction to Backbonejs for those who aren't familiar with the framework. It did a very good job at teaching the material to even those who aren't necessarily strong in Javascript. The low ranking is more or less directed towards the small projects where there are times where the questions will bring up material that was never covered in lecture slides, thus leading to confusion. Audio popping from the mic as well as poor articulation from the speaker also weren't helping. The projects that were more engaging lost details as the projects kept getting more advanced which is counterproductive as one would think as the material becomes more complicated, details for how to do the tasks and what is expected(and whats provided already to the student) should be abundantly clear.

Overall it's a good way to learn the material, I'm just glad I didn't spend $90 on this course and got it for $10 on a CyberMonday Sale :P

results.content:
I'm a developer with over 30 years experience, and these days do a fair amount of front end web development, however I'd only casually looked at Backbone and my current employers have a sizeable production system developed using it, so I wanted to get up to speed quickly.

This course was perfect for my requirements, as I was able to run through everything over a weekend, and now feel I have a good understanding of the framework, which has already helped me immensely at work.

There's plenty of good, well thought out content, and the quality of the presentation is excellent.

I'm always very wary of courses and books with titles like "The Complete Guide to....", as invariably they're nowhere near as complete as the author would like to think, but in this case there really is very good coverage of the subject.

Can't say I've looked at any of the other Backbone courses on Udemy, but there was certainly nothing I felt was left out here, and anyone completing the courses should have a good understanding of the material.

I'd certainly recommend this course, and the trainer.

results.content:
I have previously taken Backbone courses from several of the most popular online developer training sites. Learning Backbone has confounded many young developers including me. Mosh's course stands out as one of the best online courses I've ever taken, whether for Backbone or any other technology. 

Mosh's teaching style is unique. He leads the student logically through a progression of understanding in a manner akin to good unit testing. He has the uncanny ability to identify the functionality he is endeavoring to teach in each video and isolate the key points from any distraction of other related functionality so that the student can focus entirely on the discrete learning points at hand, without having unnecessary complexity layered on. With his approach, I consistently came away from each video with all the new and important concepts fully secured, ready for the next lesson. Learning web development is a challenging endeavor IMO. Mosh is an outstanding teacher whose style and methodology is something that I wish could be spread throughout the developer training industry.

Since thirteen of the lectures can be viewed for free, you should check them out for yourself if you're in the market for a great introduction to developing in Backbone. There is also a lot of bonus material in the course worth noting. One that really stands out is the lecture on Require.JS where Mosh modularizes a sample application and gives you a great running start in using Require.JS. There is also a wonderful and substantial section on testing in Backbone using Jasmine.

You can also get a great taste of Mosh's teaching style for free at his YouTube channel.

results.content:
Learn JavaScript, libraries, and frameworks is a real challenge when you don't come from a software engineering background. But Mosh makes everything accessible and straightforward. I love this project-based approach as opposed to reading a book like Developing Backbone.js Applications, which isn't the best place to start for a beginner, with it's overly detailed and tangential explanations. Thanks, Mosh, for making the fundamentals so clear! And also for quickly replying to my discussion posts :)

Update: My goal for this course was to contribute more on the front-end at my job as product designer. Yesterday, I built a new feature in Backbone Marionette that posts a form to an API endpoint—all without any assistance from my engineering team, and all thanks to this course!

results.content:
This course doesn't served me much because the real world problems that I had to solve at my company was way more deep using backbone than what was presented here.

I wish the author gave a more advanced use of backbone throughout this course. He seems knowledgeable about the topic but he didn't went to far from just showing the basic use of Backbone.

A big problem that I had throughout the course was trying to follow it and build an app at the same time. The instructor teaches you about modularizing your backbone code with requirejs in section 8, then when it we'll build a complete backbone application it does so without modularizing the application. This is pretty confusing as you don't have a complete and organized sample of how to do a complete backbone application with patterns, code organizations, etc.... You have to go forward and back at all times to try to achieve what you want to do.

This is an excellent course by the author. I have taken one of his previous courses and was thoroughly impressed, so was confident in purchasing this course. I am definitely  glad i did. 

I have previously tried a backbone course on pluralsight but this one was a lot better.

Concepts are clearly explained, the authors passion for his field definitely comes across. 

While all of the course was excellent, i particularity found the section on unit testing of immense help as unit testing is something I have always avoided learning and I feel I have a good grasp of it now.

I have always had bit of a disdain for Javascript and Jquery, I never really knew where to stuff my code, more often then not all the jquery was in one messy javascript file. But I after this course an having learnt Backbone I feel excited to make my own apps using it.

results.content:
Good intro into the basics of BackboneJs if concept-by-concept & step-by-step videos help you learn the material.  Proficiently organized and easy to understand if you have an intermediate level understanding of Javascript.  The course was adequate enough in its presentation of Backbone's Model-Collection-View structure to prepare me to work on an established professional backbone project.

Nothing in this tutorial can't be found in the documentation or various online articles.  If you are capable of training yourself without guidance using strictly those resources this course doesn't offer any extra insight.

results.content:
The course was extremely basic. It felt like only an overview or introduction to all concepts. Below improvements are needed:

- How to integrate a backbone application with Grunt. How to create a boilerplate application, run the application, create a buid package using grunt for dev or prod enrionments and then deploy the application to a server for use.
- Use some more UI components/examples like a grid, pie chart, accordian etc using complex json data as feed to load and represent the data in the respective UI components.
- Have multilple view files and using routing to redirect among different views (this is briefly explained separately but it would be great if its included in the end project).
- How to achieve session/state/data management. Suppose there are multiple users logging into the application and each user changes his/her data and that needs to reflect when they login in the future.
- Also please use require js concept to structure your application in proper MVC format as it would be for a proffessional use.

Thanks

results.content:
I recently completed Mosh's BackboneJS tutorial.

I've gone through CodeSchool's Backbone course, and a few of Pluralsight's Backbone courses (without finishing any of them). They were either too abstract, the pace was too fast, or too gimmicky. This Backbone course is different. 

Mosh presents concepts in a very clear and understandable way and the pacing is perfect. He divides the major topics into different sections (eg. Models, Collections, Views, etc). Each section has a handout/cheat sheet which I use as a tool for review or as reference. There is also a project at the end of the Models, Collections, Views, Events, and Routers sections. These projects are very helpful in that they reinforce the concepts that Mosh introduced in the section and also a very good hands-on approach to Backbone without being so overwhelming. The last section of the course is making a Todo app with Backbone. Mosh walks you through the creation of a todo app.  Mosh also introduces AMD and RequireJS, Jasmine testing framework, and a bit of HTML/CSS.

I highly recommend this course if you want an easy to understand introduction to Backbone and front-end development in general.

results.content: This was a solid course on Backbone.  Mosh obviously put a lot of thought into the way he delivered the content.  The biggest thing holding this course back from being a really great course (i feel) is that (unless I missed something) the instructor doesn't take up the section projects assigned throughout the tutorial.  You can download the completed project which does have some comments in it but if the instructor took the time to take up the section projects via video lecture, it would really drive home the content learned.   Also, would have liked a little more explanation as to why things work the way they do but that may have been beyond the scope of the course.  Overall, well done and possibly the best backbone course on Udemy.
